dt: {bc}to make secure by freeing from {d_link|dispute|dispute:2} or question

quotes.t: When she walked down the hall past his classroom, the sounds of chaos came over the frosted-glass pane above the door. She had taken to making random visits; the sight of her in the doorway {qword}quieted{/qword} the kids.

Clemens had few questions to answer about Piazza. The beanball and broken bat from 2000, and the Mets' tepid retaliation last season, were memories. And since Clemens recorded his 300th victory on June 13, the buzz around him has {qword}quieted{/qword}.
Even with that, Presser was so scared that he fled to Florida and moved from hotel to hotel till the gang war {qword}quieted{/qword} down, with his side on top.

et: Middle English {it}quieten,{/it} borrowed from Late Latin {it}quiētāre{/it} "to become quiet, make quiet, put to rest," derivative of Latin {it}quiētus{/it} "at rest, {et_link|quiet:2|quiet:2}"
shortdef: to cause to be quiet : calm
to make secure by freeing from dispute or question
to become quiet —usually used with down

dt: {bc}to become quiet or quieter {bc}to become calmer or less noisy

dt.t: The children started to {it}quiet down{/it} after dinner.
He told the crowd to {it}quiet down{/it}.

shortdef: to become quiet or quieter : to become calmer or less noisy
